At 11:30 05/10/2005, you wrote:
>This is actually a bit off topic from what you guys are talking
>about, which I would call something more like "relative"
>or "coordinate-based" labeling.  But several years ago I was asked
>whether NEAT could run in a world with no overseer.  In other words,
>does NEAT require a "global observer" on top the the system to make
>sure everything happens correctly.  An example of a world without an
>observer is one with a bunch of autonomous robots, each with their
>own genome and NN, but nothing else to decide anything about who
>should mate with whom, how many offspring, etc..
>
>Obviously, a world like that would not allow the usual NEAT
>algorithm, or even rtNEAT, but the question was really about
>historical markings.  The person was making the point that the
>historical markings would totally fail in that scenario, because
>there can be no global counters.  So the bots couldn't even mate
>with a NEAT-like crossover.
>
>But we noticed that there is a simple solution to that problem: Just
>assign totally random innovation numbers from a large range.  The
>chances that two genes get the same random number is low enough that
>it shouldn't be disruptive.  Genes could still be lined up by their
>innovation numbers even though the numbers would no longer reflect
>historical order.
>
>Anyway, the reason I mention it is because *that* system is what I'd
>really call "arbitrary" labeling.  I don't think it buys anything
>useful in a normal global-observer scenario though.

This is actually what I originally intended arbitrary labelling for.

In more advanced cases the distinction between the label on the gene 
(innovation num) and the data it read/writes (SLEAT-style fID) can get a 
bit blurred anyway...  e.g. if Gene A wants to read "output from any gene 
of type XXX" then functionally, that might equate to "any data labelled 
XXX" or it might not...

         Ian


In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
